Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible

Eje Temático Tercer Trimestre

En esta sección, los temas principales que se desarrollaran son:

Modal Verbs (Verbos Modales)
Aprenderemos a utilizar verbos modales como can, must, should, might, would, entre otros, para expresar habilidad, permiso, obligación, consejos y posibilidades. Estos verbos amplían las formas en que podemos comunicarnos en inglés, permitiendo expresar intenciones, normas y sugerencias en una variedad de contextos.

Vocabulary (Vocabulario)
Trabajaremos en la ampliación del vocabulario relacionado con estilos de vida, emociones, rutinas, actividades sociales y juveniles. Este enriquecimiento léxico fortalecerá tanto la expresión oral como escrita, mejorando nuestra capacidad para describir situaciones con mayor precisión y profundidad.

Urban Tribes (Tribus Urbanas)
Exploraremos diferentes tribus urbanas juveniles, como emos, punks, skaters, hipsters, entre otras. Este tema nos permitirá aplicar estructuras gramaticales como descripciones, comparaciones, preferencias, normas y rutinas en contextos reales y significativos. Además, fomentará la comprensión y el respeto por la diversidad cultural juvenil.
Text and Tasks
¿Cual es la importacia del vocabulario?

¿Qué es el Vocabulary?

En inglés, la palabra "vocabulary" se refiere al conjunto de palabras que una persona conoce y utiliza en un idioma. El vocabulario incluye sustantivos, verbos, adjetivos, adverbios, expresiones idiomáticas, frases comunes, y mucho más.

Dominar un idioma significa no solo conocer la gramática, sino también tener un vocabulario amplio y funcional para poder comunicarse de manera efectiva.

¿Por qué es tan importante el vocabulary en inglés?

1 . Comunicación efectiva

El vocabulario es la base de cualquier conversación. Sin palabras, no podemos decir lo que pensamos, sentimos o necesitamos. Un buen conocimiento del vocabulario te permite expresarte con claridad y comprender lo que otros te dicen.

2. Comprensión lectora y auditiva

Cuanto más vocabulario conoces, más fácil te resulta leer textos, escuchar canciones, ver películas, entender diálogos y seguir instrucciones.
Incluso si no entiendes toda la gramática, reconocer las palabras clave puede ayudarte a captar el sentido general de un mensaje.

3. Mejora de la memoria y el pensamiento

Aprender nuevas palabras estimula tu mente y mejora tu capacidad de pensar en inglés. Te permite organizar tus ideas mejor, y poco a poco, pensar sin traducir desde el español.

4. Mejora en la escritura y el habla

Un buen vocabulario te permite escribir textos más ricos y variados, y hablar de manera más natural y fluida, sin repetir siempre las mismas palabras básicas como “good”, “nice”, “big”, etc.

5. Mayor conexión con el mundo

El inglés es un idioma global. Si tienes un vocabulario amplio, puedes acceder a más información en internet, conectarte con personas de otros países, viajar, estudiar o trabajar internacionalmente.

¿Cómo se puede mejorar el vocabulary?

  • Leer frecuentemente en inglés: libros, cómics, noticias, subtítulos, etc.
  • Ver series y películas con subtítulos en inglés.
  • Usar aplicaciones de vocabulario como Quizlet, Duolingo, Memrise.
  • Hacer listas de palabras nuevas y usarlas en frases propias.
  • Repetir, practicar y revisar continuamente.


Tipos de vocabulary que debes aprender

  • Vocabulary temático: palabras sobre temas específicos (comida, deportes, tecnología, salud, etc.)
  • Vocabulary funcional: frases útiles para situaciones diarias (“Can I help you?”, “I’d like to order…”, etc.)
  • Vocabulary académico: palabras comunes en textos escolares o exámenes (“analyze”, “compare”, “result”, etc.)
  • Phrasal verbs y expresiones idiomáticas: típicas del inglés natural (“give up”, “look after”, “break the ice”)

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible

University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

El Dorado is one of the most famous legends in South America. The name means “The Golden One” in Spanish. The story originated in Colombia , where the indigenous Muisca people had a sacred ritual: they covered their new chief in gold dust and offered treasures to the gods by throwing them into the lake of Guatavita.

When Spanish explorers arrived in the early 16th century, they heard about this practice and believed it described a city made entirely of gold . They imagined a remote, mythical city hidden deep in the jungle , filled with golden temples, streets, and vast wealth. Motivated by ambition and greed , many launched dangerous expeditions to discover this unknown land.

Over time, the story shifted from a golden man to a golden city. The myth of El Dorado became a symbol of an unattainable dream , a metaphor for chasing something that may never truly exist. Even today, the expression “searching for El Dorado” refers to pursuing a goal that is likely impossible .

The legend of El Dorado shows how myths evolve, how desire can drive people to extremes, and how powerful the illusion of riches can be.

Work Bank:

legends, Golden, Colombia, ritual, chief, treasures, lake, explorers, 16th, gold, mythical, jungle, temples, wealth, greed, expeditions, man, city, dream, exist, impossible, myths, desire, riches

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Modal Vers
¿Que son Modal Verds?

Modal Verbs

¿Qué son los Modal Verbs?

Los modal verbs son verbos auxiliares especiales que se usan junto a un verbo principal para expresar ideas como:

  • Habilidad
  • Posibilidad
  • Permiso
  • Obligación
  • Consejo
  • Probabilidad

Los más comunes son: can, could, may, might, must, shall, should, will, would.

Características importantes de los Modal Verbs:

Siempre van seguidos de un verbo en forma base (sin "to"):

  • She can play the guitar.

No cambian su forma según el sujeto (no se les agrega -s, -ed, etc.):

  •  He must go.
  •  They must go.

No necesitan el auxiliar "do" para negar o hacer preguntas:

  •  Can you swim?
  •  You shouldn’t be late

Usos de los Modal Verbs con ejemplos:

1.Can/ Can't? – habilidad o permiso

  • Habilidad: I can swim.
  • Permiso: Can I go to the bathroom?
  • Negación: I can’t drive.

2. Could / Couldn’t – habilidad en el pasado, posibilidad, cortesía

  • Habilidad en el pasado: When I was 5, I could read.
  • Posibilidad: It could rain later.
  • Petición educada: Could you help me, please?

3. May / Might – posibilidad o permiso (más formal)

  • Posibilidad: It may rain tomorrow. / It might be true.
  • Permiso: May I ask a question?

4. Must / Mustn’t – obligación o prohibición

  • Obligación fuerte: You must wear a uniform.
  • Prohibición: You mustn’t use your phone here.

5. Should / Shouldn’T – consejo o sugerencia

  • Consejo: You should study for the test.
  • Advertencia: You shouldn’t eat too much candy.

6. Will / Won’t– futuro, promesas, decisiones

  • Futuro: I will visit you tomorrow.
  • Promesa: I will help you.
  • Negación: She won’t come to the party.

7. Would / Wouldn’t– deseos, peticiones formales, situaciones hipotéticas

  • Deseos: I would love to travel.
  • Peticiones formales: Would you like some coffee?
  • Hipótesis: If I were rich, I would buy a big house.

Tabla resumen de Modal Verbs:

Modal Verbs Uso principal Ejemplos
Can Habilidad, permiso i can swin
Could Pasado de "can", cortesia i could run fast / Could you help?
May Posiblilidad, permiso formal it may rain / may i come in?
Might Posibilidad (menos segura) it might snow today
Must Obligacion fuerte You must do your homework
Shall Sugerencias, ofertan shall we dance?
Should Consejo you should sleep more
Will Futuro, promesas i will call you later
Would Deseos, hipotesis i would like o coffe

Los Modal Verbs son una herramienta fundamental para expresar intenciones, necesidades, posibilidades, consejos y más. Aprenderlos bien te permitirá comunicarte de forma más clara, natural y precisa en inglés.

Sometimes, we face difficult decisions in life. You should always think carefully before acting. For example, if someone offers you something suspicious, you must not accept it. It might seem harmless at first, but it could lead to serious consequences.

When you are unsure about what to do, you ought to ask for advice. Talking to a teacher or a family member can help you see things more clearly. They may give you a different perspective or suggest something you hadn’t considered.

Looking back, you may realize that you should have made a different choice. That’s okay—everyone makes mistakes. But you must learn from them. You don’t have to be perfect, but you need to be responsible for your actions.

In the end, good choices will guide your future, and bad ones might teach you valuable lessons. So remember: you can choose wisely every day.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

The Mystery of the Bermuda Triangle

The Bermuda Triangle is one of the most mysterious areas on Earth. Some people believe that strange things happen there, like planes and ships disappearing without explanation. Experts say that we might never know the full truth about what happens in this area. Pilots and sailors should always take precautions when traveling through the region.

There are many theories about the disappearances. Some scientists think that magnetic fields may interfere with navigation systems, while others believe that natural weather patterns could be responsible. In any case, professionals agree that we must study the area carefully before drawing conclusions.

People planning to cross the triangle ought to check all equipment in advance. Ignoring safety measures can be dangerous. Even if we don’t believe in the myths, we should have learned from past mistakes by now.

Some suggest that the government might be hiding information, though there is no real evidence. What we do know is that travelers mustn’t underestimate the risks, and they need to remain alert at all times.

Urban Tribes
¿Qué son las Urban Tribes?

Tribus Urbanas


Las Urban Tribes, o Tribus Urbanas, son grupos de jóvenes que comparten intereses, estilos de vida, gustos musicales, formas de vestir, y valores comunes. Estas tribus se forman en las ciudades y se caracterizan por tener una identidad grupal fuerte. Los miembros de una tribu urbana se sienten identificados con ciertos ideales, cultura o moda, y se expresan a través de su ropa, su comportamiento, su lenguaje y sus actividades cotidianas.

Algunas de las tribus urbanas más conocidas son: punks, emos, góticos, raperos, skaters, hippies, hipsters, metaleros, otakus y gamers.


En inglés, usamos "They are...", "They usually wear...", "They like...", "They listen to..." para describir una tribu urbana.

Ejemplos:

  • Emos: They are emotional and sensitive. They usually wear black clothes and have dyed hair. They like emotional music and writing poems.
    (Son emocionales y sensibles. Usualmente usan ropa negra y tienen el cabello teñido. Les gusta la música emocional y escribir poemas.)
  • Skaters: They are active and adventurous. They usually wear loose T-shirts, jeans, and sneakers. They love skateboarding in parks.
    (Son activos y aventureros. Usualmente usan camisetas sueltas, jeans y zapatillas. Aman patinar en los parques.)


Para comparar tribus urbanas, usamos frases como "more... than", "less... than", o "as... as".

Ejemplos:

  • Emos are more emotional than skaters.
    (Los emos son más emocionales que los skaters.)
  • Goths wear darker clothes than hipsters.
    (Los góticos usan ropa más oscura que los hipsters.)
  • Skaters are as active as rappers.
    (Los skaters son tan activos como los raperos.)


Se puede usar "like", "love", "enjoy", o "hate" para expresar preferencias.

Ejemplos:

  • Otakus love watching anime and reading manga.
    (A los otakus les encanta ver anime y leer manga.)
  • Metalheads like listening to heavy metal music.
    (A los metaleros les gusta escuchar música heavy metal.)
  • Hipsters enjoy vintage fashion and indie music.
    (A los hipsters les gusta la moda vintage y la música indie.)
  • Rappers hate being stereotyped.
    (A los raperos no les gusta que los estereotipen.)


Podemos usar el presente simple para hablar de lo que hacen regularmente o las normas dentro del grupo.

Ejemplos:

  • Gamers play video games every day. They often stay up late at night.
    (Los gamers juegan videojuegos todos los días. A menudo se quedan despiertos hasta tarde.)
  • Punks follow a rebellious style. They usually reject social norms.
    (Los punks siguen un estilo rebelde. Usualmente rechazan las normas sociales.)
  • Hippies respect nature and promote peace. They never support violence.
    (Los hippies respetan la naturaleza y promueven la paz. Nunca apoyan la violencia.)
  • Goths meet at night and go to underground clubs.
    (Los góticos se reúnen en la noche y van a clubes alternativos.)


Las tribus urbanas son una forma de identidad juvenil y ayudan a los jóvenes a expresarse, encontrar amigos con gustos similares y sentirse parte de una comunidad. En inglés, aprender a describirlas te permite practicar vocabulario relacionado con ropa, personalidad, música, gustos, rutinas y comparaciones. Además, es una excelente manera de aplicar el presente simple, adjetivos, y expresiones comunes del día a día.

Emo : Youth who often express sadness, emotional intensity, and a sense of being misunderstood. Their fashion includes skinny jeans, dark eyeliner, and band T-shirts. Music preference includes bands like My Chemical Romance and Paramore.

Hippie : A peaceful and alternative group from the 1960s and 70s, known for promoting love, environmentalism, and spiritual exploration. They often wear loose clothing, tie-dye shirts, and flower accessories, and listen to psychedelic rock.

Punk : A rebellious group that emerged in the 1970s, often associated with anti-establishment attitudes. They wear leather, studs, mohawks, and often express themselves through loud, fast, aggressive music like The Sex Pistols.

Influencer : A modern, social media-driven group focused on trends, aesthetics, and appearance. They are highly active on Instagram or TikTok, and are known for following beauty standards, fashion brands, and digital influencers.

Hip-hop: A group strongly influenced by rap and urban culture. They value rhythm, street expression, freestyle, and streetwear including oversized shirts, caps, and sneakers. Music includes artists like Tupac and Kendrick Lamar.

Geek : Passionate about computers, coding, anime, and science fiction. Often introverted, they might attend comic conventions, play video games, and wear fandom merchandise from series like Star Wars or Naruto.

Raver : Energetic individuals who attend raves and electronic music festivals. They love neon colors, LED accessories, and futuristic or cyberpunk fashion. They often embrace the motto “peace, love, unity, respect”.

Skater : Youth associated with skateboarding culture, often seen at skateparks and urban spaces. Their clothing includes baggy pants, Vans or skate shoes, hoodies, and caps. They value creativity and street performance.

Emo : Youth who often express sadness, emotional intensity, and a sense of being misunderstood. Their fashion includes skinny jeans, dark eyeliner, and band T-shirts. Music preference includes bands like My Chemical Romance and Paramore.

Hippie : A peaceful and alternative group from the 1960s and 70s, known for promoting love, environmentalism, and spiritual exploration. They often wear loose clothing, tie-dye shirts, and flower accessories, and listen to psychedelic rock.

Punk : A rebellious group that emerged in the 1970s, often associated with anti-establishment attitudes. They wear leather, studs, mohawks, and often express themselves through loud, fast, aggressive music like The Sex Pistols.

Influencer : A modern, social media-driven group focused on trends, aesthetics, and appearance. They are highly active on Instagram or TikTok, and are known for following beauty standards, fashion brands, and digital influencers.

Hip-hop: A group strongly influenced by rap and urban culture. They value rhythm, street expression, freestyle, and streetwear including oversized shirts, caps, and sneakers. Music includes artists like Tupac and Kendrick Lamar.

Geek : Passionate about computers, coding, anime, and science fiction. Often introverted, they might attend comic conventions, play video games, and wear fandom merchandise from series like Star Wars or Naruto.

Raver : Energetic individuals who attend raves and electronic music festivals. They love neon colors, LED accessories, and futuristic or cyberpunk fashion. They often embrace the motto “peace, love, unity, respect”.

Skater : Youth associated with skateboarding culture, often seen at skateparks and urban spaces. Their clothing includes baggy pants, Vans or skate shoes, hoodies, and caps. They value creativity and street performance.

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text that are key to understanding the concepts. These will probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Actividad 3

Después de leer el texto sobre las tribus urbanas, el estudiante debe responder una serie de preguntas de opción múltiple relacionadas con la información presentada. Para cada pregunta, se ofrecen cuatro opciones (A, B, C y D), de las cuales solo una es la correcta. El estudiante debe seleccionar la respuesta que mejor se ajuste al contenido del texto, demostrando comprensión lectora y análisis crítico.
Text and Tasks

In modern society, urban tribes have become a way for teenagers to express their identity , beliefs, and creativity. These groups are often defined by their music taste, fashion, and culture .

For example, punks are known for their rebellious attitude and anti-system values. They often wear leather jackets, boots, and have brightly colored mohawks. Meanwhile, hippies value peace and love. They typically wear colorful clothes and are interested in spiritual causes like environmentalism.

On the other hand, emos express strong emotions through music and style. They often write poetry and enjoy emotional rock . In contrast, geeks focus on technology and pop culture. They may spend hours playing video games or watching anime series.

Some tribes, like influencers , are very present on social media. They care a lot about their image and spend time creating content. Others, like skaters , identify more with urban sports and enjoy showing off their tricks in the park .

1. A. identity B. invention C. loneliness D. religion
2. A. location B. culture C. pets D. school
3. A. silk B. leather C. wool D. denim
4.A. spiritual B. criminal C. romantic D. dangerous
5. A. documentaries B. country C. rock D. reggaeton
6. A. anime B. news C. cooking D. sports
7. A. wardrobe B. influence C. image D. energy
8. A. jungle B. park C. library D. mall
9.A. rebels B. designers C. punks D. gamers
10 A. monks B. hippies C. soldiers D. rappers
11. A. robots B. dancers C. emos D. surfers
12. A. nerds B. bloggers C. geeks D. rockers
13 .A. actors B. influencers C. artists D. models
14. A. bikers B. singers C. painters D. skaters

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Desarrollar una OVA (Objeto Virtual de Aprendizaje) interactiva para estudiantes de grado décimo que mejore el proceso de enseñanza-aprendizaje del inglés, facilitando la práctica del idioma y aumentando la motivación de los estudiantes.
Objetivos Específicos: Incorporar Ejercicios Interactivos: Desarrollar actividades prácticas que permitan a los alumnos aplicar el vocabulario y la gramática de manera lúdica y efectiva. Implementar Módulos de Autoevaluación: Diseñar herramientas de evaluación que brinden retroalimentación inmediata, ayudando a los estudiantes a identificar sus áreas de mejora. Fomentar la Adaptabilidad: Asegurar que la OVA se ajuste a diferentes niveles de habilidad y estilos de aprendizaje, garantizando que todos los estudiantes puedan beneficiarse del recurso. Evaluar el Impacto en el Aprendizaje: Realizar un seguimiento del progreso de los estudiantes y medir el impacto de la OVA en su motivación y desempeño en el aprendizaje del inglés.

Antes de iniciar esta OVA, se espera que los estudiantes:
Conozcan el alfabeto y la pronunciación básica en inglés.
Manejen vocabulario cotidiano (colores, números, saludos, etc.).
Comprendan oraciones simples en presente.
Sepan seguir instrucciones básicas en inglés.
Usen herramientas digitales de forma básica (videos, botones, audios).
Eder López, Miguel Bottia Y Eylin Gutierrez
ova diseñada para ayudar a los estudiantes que se les dificulta el inglés en decimo
Institución Educativa General Santander colgenglish1@gmail.com
